Dictionary.Name: The Collaborative International Dictionary of English v.0.44

Definition.WordDefinition:
Heritage \Her"it*age\, a. [OE. heritage, eritage, OF. heritage, eritage, F. h['e]ritage, fr. h['e]riter to inherit, LL. heriditare. See {Hereditable}.] 1. That which is inherited, or passes from heir to heir; inheritance. [1913 Webster]
Part of my heritage, Which my dead father did bequeath to me. --Shak. [1913 Webster]
2. (Script.) A possession; the Israelites, as God's chosen people; also, a flock under pastoral charge. --Joel iii. 2. --1 Peter v. 3. [1913 Webster]

heritage n 1: practices that are handed down from the past by tradition; "a heritage of freedom" 2: any attribute or immaterial possession that is inherited from ancestors; "my only inheritance was my mother's blessing"; "the world's heritage of knowledge" [syn: {inheritance}] 3: that which is inherited; a title or property or estate that passes by law to the heir on the death of the owner [syn: {inheritance}] 4: hereditary succession to a title or an office or property [syn: {inheritance}]
